text: The Ocean Bike Tour trial run is over. Now, the partners have to make some business decisions. They plan to charge each customer $350 to go on the tour. Liz suggests that they make a table or graph relating the total amount of money they collect and the number of people going. Malcolm builds on the suggestion.

Malcolm’s Strategy

  • I made a table of some examples of how to calculate the costs.
  • I used the information to write an expression to represent the total amount of money. I let n represent the number of people and T represent the amount of money collected.
  • I looked for patterns in the table to help write a rule or equation that relates the two variables.

1. What is the independent variable? What expression did Malcolm use to represent this variable?

2. What is the dependent variable? What expression did Malcolm use to represent this variable?

3. What is the cost if

  • 5 people go on the trip?
  • 10 people go on the trip?
  • 20 people go on the trip?
  • 35 people go on the trip?
  • 42 people go on the trip?
  • n people go on the trip?

4. How can Malcolm find the total amount of money collected for any number of people going on the trip?

5. What equation can Malcolm write that represents the relationship between the two variables?

1. Number of people, n.

2. Total amount of money in dollars, T.

3.

  • 5 people go on the trip? $350 more or $350 • 5 = $1,750
  • 10 people go on the trip? $350 • 10 = $3,500
  • 20 people go on the trip? $350 • 20 = $7,000
  • 35 people go on the trip? $350 • 35 = $12,250
  • 42 people go on the trip? $350 • 35 = $14,700
  • n people go on the trip? $350 times the number of people will equal the total amount of money or $350 • n = T

4. 350 times the number of people will equal the total amount of money.

5. 350 n = T

attributes.name: Total Amount of Money in Dollars (T)
